learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate advanced skills in the use of digital technologies in expressive arts
Develop collaborative creative skills in line with industry working practices
Deploy effective professional methods in collaborative project management
Design innovative uses of digital technologies for arts practice
Employ critical thinking to address important social and cultural issues

assessments.task_description:
Task Description:

Students will be required to make a 5 minute live presentation of an initial digital arts project idea. The presentation can be made using any medium, but must make a clear and compelling case for the idea and outcome. The presentation should clearly explain the concept, situate the project within the broader field of digital arts practice and be inspiring to the audience.

The project pitch should include information on:

  1. Artistic Concept and Inspiration
  2. Creative Goals
  3. Choice of Medium
  4. Application and Development of Your Creative Skills


  • All presentations will be recorded for marking purposes via recording facilities available where the assessment takes place (eg. ECHO360, Zoom, camera device)  
  • Recordings will be retained by the School of Communication and Arts for at least 12 months from the release of the final grade for the course.  
  • Recordings will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed by authorised school staff for the purposes of: 
  • Moderation of marking;  
  • Provision of feedback to the student(s) recorded; and/or  
  • Re-marking following a successful re-mark application. 


Criteria & Marking:

1) Proof of Concept - An effective and persuasive presentation of the concept, context and ambitions of the project (25%)

2) Artistic Context - A clear statement of motivation, inspiration, intent and execution in reference to the broader field of digital arts (25%)

3) Media Mix - An informed, innovative, and practical assessment of the chosen medium and design tools (25%)

4) Creative Skills- A robust assessment of the presenter's existing skills set and identification of skills acquisition in this project (25%).


Submission: This assessment will be undertaken live in the scheduled workshop in Week 4.

A comprehensive description of this assessment and grading rubric will be available in Blackboard.

Use of AI Tools

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Late submission is not possible for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.assessment_title: Digital Arts Project Plan in Week 8
assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Product/ Design, Project
assessments.task_description:
Task Description:

Each group should submit a full Digital Arts project design brief using the template provided in Blackboard (approx. 2500 words plus graphical materials).

This will include:

1) Project title and summary,

2) Creative intention, technical logistics and production schedule,

3) Composition, roles and biographies of group members, and

4) Creative process demonstration via 2D representation of working ideas and plans.


Objectives:

  • Develop a theoretically-grounded framework for conceiving and creating digital art
  • Demonstrate project management and planning skills for your project
  • Articulate the relationship between critical thinking and practical implementation
  • Identify and plan for your skill development needs
  • Provide a clear and achievable timeline for developing your project


Criteria & Marking:

1) Project Aims and Quality - An effective and persuasive presentation of the concept, context and ambitions of the project, supported by a compelling written project summary

(25%)

2) Project Design Skills - including clear statements of motivation, inspiration, intent and execution supported by demonstrated attention to media mix, technical and logistical planning and production schedule (25%)

3) Project Management Skills - The composition and organisation of a high quality project team, demonstrating the utilisation and acquisition of appropriate skills for collaborative creative production (25%)

4) Documentation of Creative Process - Demonstration of creative design skills via documentation of ideas, prototypes and projects plans (25%). The project plan will serve as a comprehensive roadmap for your final digital arts project, combining theoretical frameworks with practical execution strategies. This document should demonstrate your critical understanding of digital culture and technologies while outlining concrete steps for project completion.

A comprehensive description of this assessment and grading rubric will be available in Blackboard.

Use of AI Tools

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Digital Arts Prototype Presentation in Week 13
assessments.mode: Activity/ Performance, Oral, Product/ Artefact/ Multimedia
assessments.category: Creative Production/ Exhibition, Presentation, Product/ Design, Project
assessments.task_description:
Task Description:

In our final session in Week 13, project groups will provide an in-class demonstration / performance of their digital arts project prototype. This will entail a 20-minute group presentation (25 of 50 marks) of the prototype work (25 of 50 marks) that shows the work at its present stage of execution and clearly explains:

• The creative concept and social context of the work

• The aesthetic and technical composition of the work

• The decisions that have been taken in the design process

• The work remaining and issues to be addressed before taking this project public

• The skills developed and lessons learned from designing this project

Each performance will be followed by a five minute Q and A session with the COMU3201 class and tutor.

Each group should also submit the working files for their prototype on a USB stick directly to the course convenor at the assessment session.


Criteria & Marking:

 Concept, Cohesion and Planning (25%)

 •          Was the concept of the prototype well conceived?

•          Were the components of the prototype well integrated?

•          Was the prototype designed to suit an identified audience?

•          Was the prototype sufficiently developed / rehearsed?

•          Was there evidence of effective team work and planning?

 Form and Function (25%)

 •          How innovative was the use of digital technologies?

•          How effective was the integration of technologies?

•          Was the concept of digital arts clearly explored?

•          Was the presented prototype appropriate for public exhibition?

•          Were the production values at an appropriate standard?

 Aesthetics (25%)

 •          How compelling was the chosen media mix in artistic terms?

•          Was there evidence of originality in terms of style, motifs and expression?

•          Was the context, purpose and meaning of the piece sufficiently articulated?

•          How good was the performance as an artistic production?

•          Was there sufficient merit in the work in artistic terms?

 Professional Standards (25%)

 •          Were the performers well composed in their self-presentation?

•          Was the work sufficiently polished/finished for public presentation?

•          Was the work comparable with professional outputs in the relevant field?

•          How exciting/stimulating was the performance?

•          How well received was the performance?


The presentation and prototype of the project will be marked as a live event. The rubric for assessment will be available on Blackboard.


Please note that all of the material presented must be original and free of copyrighted material. This is a legal requirement of public performance, and a professional norm for serious creative works.

Please note: this is a class assessment item and students are NOT able to apply for an extension via the Unitask portal. In extremis, please contact your course coordinator directly to see if alternative arrangements are available.

Submission:

In class:

Recording of Oral and Practical Assessment

All presentations will be recorded for marking purposes via recording facilities available where the assessment takes place (eg. ECHO360, Zoom, camera device)

Recordings will be retained by the School of Communication and Arts for at least 12 months from the release of the final grade for the course.

Recordings will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed by authorised school staff for the purposes of:

• Moderation of marking;

• Provision of feedback to the student(s) recorded; and/or

• Re-marking following a successful re-mark application

Use of AI Tools

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
